title-group.article-title: The periodic traveling waves in a diffusive periodic SIR epidemic model with nonlinear incidence

contrib-group.aff: College of Mathematics and System Science, Xinjiang University, Urumqi 830046, People’s Republic of China

abstract.p: In this paper, a reaction-diffusion SIR epidemic model is proposed. It takes into account the individuals mobility, the time periodicity of the infection rate and recovery rate, and the general nonlinear incidence function, which contains a number of classical incidence functions. In our model, due to the introduction of the general nonlinear incidence function, the boundedness of the infected individuals can not be obtained, so we study the existence and nonexistence of periodic traveling wave solutions of original system with the aid of auxiliary system. The basic reproduction number R0 and the critical wave speed c* are given. We obtained the existence and uniqueness of periodic traveling waves for each wave speed c>c* using the Schauder’s fixed points theorem when R0>1. The nonexistence of periodic traveling waves for two cases (i) R0>1 and 0<c<c*, (ii) R0≤1 and c≥0 are also obtained. These results generalize and improve the existing conclusions. Finally, the numerical experiments support the theoretical results. The differences of traveling wave solution between periodic system and general aperiodic coefficient system are analyzed by numerical simulations.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Consider the several outbreaks of infectious disease in human history, such as the Black Death in the late Middle Ages, from the 16th to the 18th century, smallpox, measles, typhoid fever, plague, in the middle of the 20th century, Ebola, SARS and bird flu, these infectious diseases have brought huge impacts on human society. Most recently, in 2020, the COVID-19 outbreak has spread globally in just a few months and has infected more than 50 million people, killed more than one million two hundred as of mid-November 2020, and had an incalculable impact on human lives and the global economy. In the history of mankind, the researches on this kind of terrible infectious disease have never stopped, and the prediction, prevention and control of the disease spread are the research focus. It is a straightforward and effective way to study the spread and control of disease applying appropriate mathematical models.

Besides, to make the model better reflects or describes the real environment, traveling wave solutions, as a special form solution, have been studied more and more widely, the traveling wave solutions cover a wide range of fields, such as in chemical reactions, biological population, genetic engineering, fluid mechanics, mathematical ecology, etc. (See [1], [2], [3], [4], [5], [6]). Particularly, in the epidemic models, traveling wave solutions can be understood as a state of disease propagation in space at a specific speed from a certain area to the surroundings. The existence of traveling waves and the minimum wave speed have important significance for the prediction and control of diseases (See [7], [8], [9], [10], [11], [12], [13], [14], [15]). At present, the traveling waves for autonomous reaction-diffusion and nonlocal diffusion epidemic models have been studied extensively. Some important results can be found in the literatures [7], [8], [9], [10], [13], [16], [17], [18], [19], [20], [21], [22], [23] and their references.

On the other hand, we know that the disease transmission coefficient and recovery rate are not always constant, due to the influence of factors such as weather, temperature, season and so on (See [24], [25], [26], [27], [28], [29], [30] and references therein). Consequently, the nonautonomous (especially, time periodic) systems have received widespread attention from scholars [31], [32], [33], [35]. In [31], Zhang et al. proposed the following reaction-diffusion SIR model with time-dependent(1){∂S∂t=d1ΔS(t,x)−β(t)S(t,x)I(t,x),∂I∂t=d2ΔI(t,x)+β(t)S(t,x)I(t,x)−γ(t)I(t,x),∂R∂t=d3ΔR(t,x)+γ(t)I(t,x),

It is worth noting that, different from the previous model with constant transmission rate and recovery rate in [34], this model presents the traveling waves of periodic parabolic systems, which render the previous methods in [34] unusable. In order to effectively break through these problems, the authors turn the problem into a truncated problem, and then investigate the periodic traveling waves by applying some limiting arguments. They established the existence of periodic traveling waves when wave speed c is large than critical wave speed c*=2d2T∫0T[β(t)−γ(t)]dt and the basic reproduction number R0=∫0Tβ(t)dt∫0Tγ(t)dt>1. They also obtained the nonexistence for either R0≤1 or c<c* and R0>1.

Recently, Wang et al. in [35] investigated the following reaction-diffusion time periodic SIR model(2){∂S∂t=d1ΔS(t,x)−β(t)S(t,x)I(t,x)S(t,x)+I(t,x),∂I∂t=d2ΔI(t,x)+β(t)S(t,x)I(t,x)S(t,x)+I(t,x)−γ(t)I(t,x),∂R∂t=d3ΔR(t,x)+γ(t)I(t,x).The authors have used fixed-point theories to investigate the periodic traveling waves. Theoretical results show that the system has periodic traveling waves for each wave speed c large than the critical value c*=2d2T∫0T[β(t)−γ(t)]dt when the basic reproduction number R0=∫0Tβ(t)dt∫0Tγ(t)dt>1, and there is no periodic traveling wave when R0≤1 or R0>1 and c<c*.

It is well known that the incidence function in many infectious disease models are bilinear or standard incidence. From the perspective of the development mechanism of infectious diseases, the bilinear incidence is generally used for small-scale susceptible group and exposure. As the population size increases, the bilinear incidence will become infinite and lose its practical significance. At this time, the standard incidence is adopted, which is applicable to a large number of people. However, more and more nonlinear incidence have been mentioned many times (See [36], [37], [38]). Korobeinikov and Maini in [39] investigated the the nonlinear incidence f(S)g(I) in a variety of epidemic models. So here, we wonder if the system has a variety of incidence functions, can we come to the same conclusions? Incorporating these above factors, it is then very interesting and natural to investigate the periodic traveling wave solution of periodic epidemic model with general nonlinear incidence.

Motivated by the articles in [31], [35], we investigate the following reaction-diffusion time periodic SIR epidemic model with general nonlinear incidence:(3){∂S∂t=d1ΔS(t,x)−β(t)f(S(t,x),I(t,x)),∂I∂t=d2ΔI(t,x)+β(t)f(S(t,x),I(t,x))−γ(t)I(t,x),∂R∂t=d3ΔR(t,x)+γ(t)I(t,x),where S, I and R denote the sizes of susceptible, infective and removed individuals in location x and at time t, respectively; di≥0(i=1,2,3) stand for the diffusion coefficients for the three individuals, respectively; β(t) and γ(t) are considered as strictly positive and T-periodic functions; the term f(S,I) is the nonlinear incidence.

It is worth mentioning that our model makes the boundedness of infected individuals difficult to obtain due to the introduction of general response function, which will lead to the Schauder’s fixed point theorem cannot be used like in [31] and [35]. To overcome these difficulties, we have to establish an auxiliary system to further construct a bounded closed convex set, and use the fixed point theorem to obtain the traveling wave solution of the auxiliary system, and use the Arzela`-Ascoli theorem to extract diagonal elements to obtain the existence of the traveling wave solution of the system (3).

This paper is organized as follows. Next Section, some important lemmas are introduced and the critical wave speed c* and the basic reproduction number R0 are given. Furthermore, the auxiliary system is introduced. In Section 3, a pair of sub- and super-solutions are constructed for the auxiliary system. In Section 4, the convex and closed set is constructed. The fixed point problems derivation from model (3) are discussed. In Section 5, the existence of periodic travelling wave solutions will be firstly proved for the auxiliary system. Then, the corresponding conclusions are further proved for model (3). In Section 6, we study the nonexistence of periodic traveling wave solutions. Section 7, the numerical examples are given to verify our conclusions and a simple comparison is made with the general aperiodic model. Lastly, in Section 8, a brief conclusion is given.

sec.title: Preliminary
sec.p: We first introduce some notations, important lemmas and definitions to be used in the next sections.

Denote R=(−∞,+∞), R+=[0,+∞), N and N+ be the sets of natural numbers and positive natural numbers, respectively. Denote Γ:=BUC(R,R) be a Banach space of bounded and uniformly continuous functions with the supremum norm. Let Γ+:={ν∈Γ:ν(ξ)≥0,ξ∈R}. From Theorem 1.5 in [40] we know that the Γ-realization dΔΓ of dΔ generates a strongly continuous analytic semigroup T(t) on Γ and T(t)Γ+⊂Γ+ for any t≥0. Additionally, from (Section 2, [31]) or (Chapter I, [40]) we obtain(4)(T(t)ν)(ξ)=14πdt∫Re−(ξ−z)24dtν(z)dz,t>0,ξ∈R,ν(·)∈Γ.

For any given constants μ>0 and T>0, let BUC([0,T]×R,R) be a space of uniformly bounded and uniformly continuous functions [0,T]×R↦R. DefineBμ([0,T]×R,R2):={ν=(ν1,ν2):νi∈BUC([0,T]×R,R),supt∈[0,T],ξ∈R{e−μ|ξ||νi(t,ξ)|}<∞,νi(0,ξ)=νi(T,ξ),ξ∈R,i=1,2.}with the norm∥ν∥μ:=max{supt∈[0,T],ξ∈Re−μ|ξ||ν1(t,ξ)|,supt∈[0,T],ξ∈Re−μ|ξ||ν2(t,ξ)|}.

Next, we need to introduce the following important lemmas on the parabolic initial value problems and Harnack inequalities (See [41], [42]), which will be used in the proofs of Lemma 10 and Theorem 3, respectively.Lemma 1
(See[42]) Letρ(t,x)∈C([0,T]×R,R),initial valueμ0∈C(R). Set(5)μ(t,x)=(T(t)μ0)(x)+∫0tT(t−s)ρ(s,·)ds(x),t∈[0,T],x∈Rn.Then,μ(t,x)∈C([0,T]×R)∩Cθ,2θ([ϵ,T]×R)for eachϵ∈(0,T)andθ∈(0,1). Furthermore, the following inequalities hold for some constantsM>0andM(ϵ,θ)>0(6)∥μ∥∞≤M(∥μ0∥∞+∥ρ∥∞),and(7)∥μ∥Cθ,2θ([ϵ,T]×R)≤M(ϵ,θ)(ϵ−θ∥μ0∥∞+∥ρ∥∞),where∥μ∥∞=sup(t,x)∈[0,T]×R∥μ(t,x)∥,∥μ∥Cθ,2θ([ϵ,T]×R)=supx∈R∥μ(·,x)∥Cθ([ϵ,T])+sup0≤t≤T∥μ(t,·)∥C2θ(R). Lemma 2
(See[43]) (Harnack inequalities) Let the operatorsLi:=∑j,k=1naj,ki(t,ξ)∂2∂ξj∂ξk+∑j=1nbji(t,ξ)∂∂ξj−∂∂t,i=1,2,…,l,be uniformly parabolic in an open domain(τ,M)×ΩofR×Rn,that is, there existsα0>0such that the inequality∑j,k=1naj,ki(t,ξ)ξjξk≥α0∑j=1nξj2always holds for every(ξ1,ξ2,…,ξn)∈Rn,where−∞<τ<M≤+∞andΩis a bounded open set. Assume thataj,ki(t,ξ),bji(t,ξ)∈C((τ,M)×Ω,R)and satisfymax(t,ξ)∈(τ,M)×Ω|aj,ki(t,ξ)|+|bji(t,ξ)|≤β0for someβ0>0. Suppose thatw=(ω1,ω2,…,ωl)∈C((τ,M)×Ω¯,Rl)C1,2((τ,M)×Ω,Rl)satisfies(8)∑s=1lci,s(t,ξ)ωs+Liωi≤0,(t,ξ)∈(τ,M)×Ω,i=1,2,…,l,whereci,s(t,ξ)∈C((τ,M)×Ω,R)andci,s≥0ifi≠s,and there exists a constantγ0>0such thatmax(t,ξ)∈(τ,M)×Ω|ci,s(t,ξ)|≤γ0,i,s=1,2,…,l.Assume thatD⊂⊂U⊂Ωand there exist some positive constantsϱandϵsuch that dist(D¯,∂U)>ϱand|D|>ϵ. Letθ>0andτ+4θ>M,then there exist positive constantsp,ω1andω2dependent onα0,β0,γ0,ϱ,ϵ,n,diamΩandθsatisfyinginf(τ+3θ,τ+4θ)×Dωk≥ω1[(ωk)+]p,(τ+θ,τ+2θ)×D−ω2maxj=1,2,…,ksupτ×U[τ,τ+4θ)×∂U(ωj)−.Where(ωk)+=max{ωk,0},(ωk)−=max{−ωk,0},[(ωk)+]p,Ω=(1|Ω|∫Ω|(ωk)+|pdxdt)1p,particularly,[(ωk)+]∞,Ω=supΩ|(ωk)+|. Furthermore, if all inequalities in(8)become equalities, then the lemma is also valid forp=∞andω1,ω2independent ofϵ.
In this paper, for the convenience, let f(ξ) with ξ=(ξ1,ξ2,…,ξn) be a continuously differentiable function, we denote fξi(ξ)=∂f(ξ)∂ξi.
For nonlinear incidence f(S,I) in model (3) in this paper we always assume that the following assumptions hold.
(A1)f(S,I) is twice continuously differentiable for S,I≥0 and f(0,I)=f(S,0)=0 for all S,I>0.
(A2)fI(S,I)>0 and fII(S,I)≤0 for all S>0 and I≥0. For any fixed I≥0, fS(S,I) is positive and bounded for all S≥0.

There are some concrete incidence functions satisfying assumptions (A1) and (A2), such as f(S,I)=SI (See [31]), f(S,I)=SIS+I (See [35]), f(S,I)=SI1+kI with constant k≥0 (See [43]) and f(S,I)=SI1+aS+bI with constants a,b≥0 (See [44]).

Because the first two equations of (3) are relatively independent, it suffices to consider the reduced system(9){∂S∂t=d1ΔS(t,x)−β(t)f(S(t,x),I(t,x)),∂I∂t=d2ΔI(t,x)+β(t)f(S(t,x),I(t,x))−γ(t)I(t,x). Definition 1
The T-periodic traveling wave of system (9) is defined as a special solution (S(t,x),I(t,x))=(ϕ(t,z),φ(t,z)) with z=x+ct satisfying(10)(ϕ(t+T,z),φ(t+T,z))≡(ϕ(t,z),φ(t,z)).
Obviously, such solutions (ϕ(t,z),φ(t,z)) with z=x+ct must satisfy(11){ϕt(t,z)=d1ϕzz(t,z)−cϕz(t,z)−β(t)f(ϕ(t,z),φ(t,z)),φt(t,z)=d2φzz(t,z)−cφz(t,z)+β(t)f(ϕ(t,z),φ(t,z))−γ(t)φ(t,z).

In this paper, we investigate the traveling wave solutions (ϕ(t,x+ct),φ(t,x+ct)) of system (9) satisfying the following asymptotic boundary conditions(12)(ϕ(t,−∞)φ(t,−∞))=(S00),(ϕ(t,∞)φ(t,∞))=(S∞0)uniformlyfort∈R.Here S0>0 is thought to be the sizes of susceptible individuals in the initial state. The constant S∞≥0 stands for the sizes of susceptible individuals after the epidemic. Define the basic reproduction number of periodic system (9) as belowR0:=∫0Tβ(t)fI(S0,0)dt∫0Tγ(t)dt.In fact, R0 reflects the average number of newly infected individuals generated by a single infected individual at the beginning of the disease infection process.

Linearizing the second equation of system (11) at (S0,0), yields(13)Mt=d2Mzz(t,z)−cMz(t,z)+(β(t)fI(S0,0)−γ(t))M(t,z).DefineΘc(λ)=d2λ2−cλ+ω,c∈R,λ∈R,where ω:=1T∫0T(β(t)fI(S0,0)−γ(t))dt. Clearly, ω>0 if and only if R0=∫0Tβ(t)fI(S0,0)dt∫0Tγ(t)dt>1. Letλ1=c−c2−4d2ω2d2andλ2=c+c2−4d2ω2d2.If c>c*:=2d2ω, then we have Θc(λ1)=Θc(λ2)=0 and Θc(λ)<0 for all λ∈(λ1,λ2).

In this paper, we will consider the periodic travelling wave solutions for model (3) by using the auxiliary system method. We introduce the auxiliary system(14){ϕt(t,z)=d1ϕzz(t,z)−cϕz(t,z)−β(t)f(ϕ(t,z),φ(t,z)),φt(t,z)=d2φzz(t,z)−cφz(t,z)+β(t)f(ϕ(t,z),φ(t,z))−γ(t)φ(t,z)−εφ2(t,z),where ε>0 is a constant. Our idea is that firstly we will discuss the existence of travelling wave solution (ϕε(t,z),φε(t,z)) which is dependent of parameter ε for auxiliary system (14) with the asymptotic boundary conditions (12) when R0>1 and c>c* by using the sub- and super-solutions method and the fixed point theorems. Then taking ε→0, we will further prove that there exists the limit function (ϕ*(t,z),φ*(t,z)) of (ϕε(t,z),φε(t,z)), which is the travelling wave solution of model (3) with the asymptotic boundary conditions (12) when R0>1 and c>c*.

sec.title: Sub- and super-solutions
sec.p:
In what follows, we always assume that R0>1 and c>c*. Define function K(t)=exp(∫0t[d2λ12−cλ1+(β(s)fI(S0,0)−γ(s))]ds). We easily verify K(t+T)=K(t) for all t≥0. Letϕ+(t,z):=S0,ϕ−(t,z):=max{S0(1−M1eε1z),0},φ+(t,z):=K(t)eλ1z,φ−(t,z):=max{K(t)eλ1z(1−M2eε2z),0},where t>0,z∈R. Parameters Mi and εi(i=1,2) are positive constants and will be given later. Now, we will prove that (ϕ−,φ−) and (ϕ+,φ+) are the upper-lower solutions of system (14).Lemma 3
Functionϕ+(t,z)=S0satisfies the inequalityϕt+≥d1ϕzz+−cϕz+−β(t)f(ϕ+,φ−).

The proof of Lemma 3 is simple since β(t)f(ϕ+,φ−)≥0.Lemma 4
Functionφ+(t,z)=K(t)eλ1zsatisfies the inequalityφt+≥d2φzz+−cφz++β(t)f(ϕ+,φ+)−γ(t)φ+−εφ+2. Proof
By a simple calculation, we get(15)φt+(t,z)=K′(t)eλ1z=[d2λ12−cλ1+(β(t)fI(S0,0)−γ(t))]K(t)eλ1z=d2φzz+−cφz++(β(t)fI(S0,0)−γ(t))φ+.Assumption (A2) implies that f(ϕ+,φ+)≤fI(S0,0)φ+ for φ+≥0. Thus(16)d2φzz+−cφz++β(t)f(ϕ+,φ+)−γ(t)φ+−εφ+2≤d2φzz+−cφz++β(t)fI(S0,0)φ+−γ(t)φ+=φt+(t,z).This is end of the proof. □ Lemma 5
Suppose0<ε1<min{λ1,cd1}andM1>1large enough, then functionϕ−(t,z)satisfies the inequality(17)ϕt−−d1ϕzz−+cϕz−≤−β(t)f(ϕ−,φ+),for anyz≠z1:=−ε1−1lnM1. Proof
If z>−ε1−1lnM1, then ϕ−(t,z)=0 and (17) holds. If z<−ε1−1lnM1, then ϕ−(t,z)=S0(1−M1eε1z) and φ+(t,z)=K(t)eλ1z. The inequality (17) is equivalent tod1S0M1ε12eε1z−cS0M1ε1eε1z≤−β(t)f(S0(1−M1eε1z),K(t)eλ1z),that is,(18)S0M1ε1(c−d1ε1)≥β(t)f(S0(1−M1eε1z),K(t)eλ1z)eε1z.From assumptions (A1) and (A2) one can see that f(S0(1−M1eε1z),K(t)eλ1z)<f(S0,K(t)eλ1z) andf(S0,K(t)eλ1z)eε1z=K(t)f(S0,K(t)eλ1z)K(t)eε1z≤fI(S0,0)K(t).To obtain inequality (18), it is sufficient to verify(19)S0M1ε1(c−d1ε1)≥β(t)fI(S0,0)K(t).Noting the periodicity and positivity of β(t) and K(t), keeping 0<ε1<min{λ1,cd1} and taking M1>1 sufficiently large, then inequality (19) holds. This proof is completed. □ Lemma 6
Assume thatε2∈(0,min{ε1,λ2−λ1})small enough andM2>1large enough such that−ε2−1lnM2<−ε1−1lnM1. Then functionφ−(t,z)satisfies the inequality(20)φt−−d2φzz−+cφz−≤β(t)f(ϕ−,φ−)−γ(t)φ−−εφ−2,for anyz≠z2:=−ε2−1lnM2. Proof
It follows from −ε2−1lnM2<−ε1−1lnM1 that z2<z1<0. If z>−ε2−1lnM2, then φ−(t,z)=0, which implies that (20) holds. If z<−ε2−1lnM2, then φ−(t,z)=K(t)eλ1z(1−M2eε2z) and ϕ−(t,z)=S0(1−M1eε1z). Rewriting inequality (20), we have(21)φt−−d2φzz−+cφz−−(β(t)fI(S0,0)−γ(t))φ−≤β(t)[f(ϕ−,φ−)−fI(S0,0)φ−]−εφ−2.By direct calculations, we can obtainφt−−d2φzz−+cφz−−(β(t)fI(S0,0)−γ(t))φ−=eε1z[K′(t)−d2λ12K(t)+cλ1K(t)−(β(t)fI(S0,0)−γ(t))K(t)]−M2e(λ1+ε2)z[K′(t)−d2(λ1+ε2)2K(t)+c(λ1+ε2)K(t)−(β(t)fI(S0,0)−γ(t))K(t)]=−M2e(λ1+ε2)zK(t)[(d2λ12−cλ1)−(d2(λ1+ε2)2−c(λ1+ε2))]=M2e(λ1+ε2)zK(t)Θc(λ1+ε2).Then inequality (21) is equivalent to(22)−M2e(λ1+ε2)zK(t)Θc(λ1+ε2)≥β(t)[fI(S0,0)φ−−f(ϕ−,φ−)]+εφ−2.Assumption (A2) implies that f(S,I)I is a decreasing function on (0,+∞). Thus, for any given ϵ∈(0,fI(S0,0)), we can find a number σ0>0 such that f(S,I)I≥fI(S0,0)−ϵ as S0−σ0<S<S0 and 0<I<σ0. Since φ−→0 and ϕ−→S0 as z→−∞, for given above ϵ∈(0,fI(S0,0)), we can choose a M2′>0 such that 0<φ−<σ0 and S0−σ0≤ϕ−≤S0 when z<−M2′. Let M2>max{M1ε2/ε1,eε2M2′}, then we get(23)fI(S0,0)φ−−f(ϕ−,φ−)=(fI(S0,0)−f(ϕ−,φ−)φ−)φ−≤(fI(S0,0)−f(ϕ−,φ−)φ−+φ−2)2≤(fI(S0,0)−(fI(S0,0)−ϵ)+φ−)2.Due to inequality (23) is valid for any ϵ∈(0,fI(S0,0)), which implies that fI(S0,0)φ−−f(ϕ−,φ−)≤φ−2. That is,(24)β(t)[fI(S0,0)φ−−f(ϕ−,φ−)]+εφ−2≤(β(t)+ε)φ−2.Noting (24), to obtain (22), it suffices to verify(25)−M2e(λ1+ε2)zK(t)Θc(λ1+ε2)≥(β(t)+ε)K2(t)e2λ1z(1−M2eε2z)2.In view of 0<(1−M2eε2z)2<1, to obtain (25) it suffices to verify(26)−M2e(λ1+ε2)zK(t)Θc(λ1+ε2)≥(β(t)+ε)K2(t)e2λ1z.That is,(27)−M2Θc(λ1+ε2)≥(β(t)+ε)K(t)e(λ1−ε2)z.Since ε2<min{ε1,λ2−λ1} and 0<ε1<λ1, we have λ1−ε2>0. Hence, for z<−ε2−1lnM2, it is sufficient to verify−M2Θc(λ1+ε2)≥(β(t)+ε)K(t)M2ε2−λ1ε2.In fact, it is easy to see that λ1+ε2∈(λ1,λ2) and Θc(λ1+ε2)<0. The above inequality is true for M2>max{M1ε2/ε1,eε2M2′} large enough. The proof of this lemma is shown. □

sec.title: Fixed-point problems
sec.p: Now, we construct a set D as followsD:={(ϕ˜,φ˜)∈Bμ([0,T]×R,R2):ϕ−≤ϕ˜≤ϕ+,φ−≤φ˜≤min{φ+,Λε}},where Λε>0 is sufficiently large constant satisfying β(t)f(S0,Λε)−γ(t)Λε−εΛε2<0 for all t∈[0,T]. In fact, we can choose Λε=maxt∈[0,T]{β(t)fI(S0,0)−γ(t)ε}. For any (ϕ˜,φ˜)∈D, letf1[ϕ˜,φ˜]=α1ϕ˜−β(t)f(ϕ˜,φ˜),f2[ϕ˜,φ˜]=α2φ˜+β(t)f(ϕ˜,φ˜)−γ(t)φ˜−εφ˜2,where α1 and α2 are positive constants satisfying α1>max{mβ^,ln4T} with β^:=maxt∈[0,T]β(t), m:=sup0≤S≤S0{fS(S,Λε)} and α2>maxt∈[0,T]γ(t)+2εΛε. For a given (ϕ˜,φ˜)∈D, we investigate the following parabolic initial value problem:(28){ϕt−d1ϕzz+cϕz+α1ϕ=f1[ϕ˜,φ˜],0<t≤T,z∈R,φt−d2φzz+cφz+α2φ=f2[ϕ˜,φ˜],0<t≤T,z∈R,ϕ(0,z)=ϕ0(z),φ(0,z)=φ0(z),z∈R.Rewrite (28) as an integral system:(29){ϕ(t)=T1(t)ϕ0+∫0tT1(t−s)f1[ϕ˜,φ˜](s)ds,φ(t)=T2(t)φ0+∫0tT2(t−s)f2[ϕ˜,φ˜](s)ds,where (ϕ(t),φ(t))=(ϕ(t,z),φ(t,z)) and Ti(t) is the analytic semigroup (See [41]) generated by operator Ai:D(Ai)→C(R) defined by Aiν=diνzz−cνz−αiν,i=1,2, andD(Ai):={ν∈⋂1≤p<∞Wloc2,p(R):Aiν∈C(R)},i=1,2,where the space Wloc2,p(R) can be found in [40]. Furthermore, from (4) we have(30)(Ti(t)ν)(x)=e−αit14πdit∫Re−(x−ct−ξ)24ditν(ξ)dξ,t>0,x∈R,ν(·)∈Γ.The solution of integral system (29) is the mild solution of problem (28). For a given η>0, defineB˜η(R,R2):={ν=(ν1,ν2):νi∈Γ,supξ∈Re−η|ξ||νi(ξ)|<∞,ξ∈R,i=1,2},equipped with the norm|ν|μ:=max{supξ∈Re−η|ξ||ν1(ξ)|,supξ∈Re−η|ξ||ν2(ξ)|}.LetD˜:={(ϕ0(·),φ0(·))∈B˜η(R,R2):ϕ−(0,z)≤ϕ0(z)≤ϕ+(0,z)φ−(0,z)≤φ0(z)≤min{φ+(0,z),Λε}}.Obviously, D˜ is convex and closed set. Next, we show that the system (29) has a unique solution (ϕ*,φ*)∈D for any (ϕ˜,φ˜)∈D.

Now, we show that the invariance of integral system (29). To obtain this, we introduce the following Lemma.Lemma 7
The functionsϕ+,φ+,ϕ−andφ−satisfy the following inequalities:(31)ϕ+(t)≥T1(t)ϕ+(0)+∫0tT1(t−s)f1[ϕ+,φ−](s)ds,(32)φ+(t)≥T2(t)φ+(0)+∫0tT2(t−s)f2[ϕ+,φ+](s)ds,(33)ϕ−(t)≤T1(t)ϕ−(0)+∫0tT1(t−s)f1[ϕ−,φ+](s)dsand(34)φ−(t)≤T2(t)φ−(0)+∫0tT2(t−s)f2[ϕ−,φ−](s)ds. Proof
Since ϕ+(t,z)≡S0 and A1ϕ=d1ϕzz−cϕz−α1ϕ, we haveϕt+(t)=d1ϕzz+(t)−cϕz+(t)−α1ϕ+(t)+α1ϕ+(t)=A1ϕ+(t)+α1ϕ+(t).Since the positivity of semigroup T1(t), we know thatϕt+=T1(t)ϕ+(0)+∫0tT1(t−s)α1ϕ+(s)ds≥T1(t)ϕ+(0)+∫0tT1(t−s)[α1ϕ+(s)−β(s)f(ϕ+(s),φ−(s))]ds=T1(t)ϕ+(0)+∫0tT1(t−s)f1[ϕ+,φ−](s)ds,which implies that inequality (31) holds.
From the Eq. (15) in Lemma 4 and A2φ=d2φzz−cφz−α2φ, we know thatφt+=d2φzz+−cφz++(β(t)fI(S0,0)−γ(t))φ+=A2φ++α2φ+(t)+(β(t)fI(S0,0)−γ(t))φ+(t).Since the positivity of semigroup T2(t), one hasφ+(t)=T2(t)φ+(0)+∫0tT2(t−s)[α2φ+(s)+(β(s)fI(S0,0)−γ(s))φ+(s)]ds≥T2(t)φ+(0)+∫0tT2(t−s)[α2φ+(s)+β(s)f(ϕ+(s),φ+(s))−γ(s)φ+(s)−εφ+2(s)]ds=T2(t)φ+(0)+∫0tT2(t−s)f2[ϕ+,φ+](s)ds.Hence, inequality (32) holds.
Next, we consider ϕ−(t) and φ−(t). Wherein we let ϕ^−(t,z)=ϕ−(t,z+ct) and φ^+(t,z)=φ+(t,z+ct), (t,z)∈[0,T]×R. It follows from Lemma 5 thatϕ^t−(t,z)−d1ϕ^zz−(t,z)+α1ϕ^−(t,z)−f1[ϕ^,φ^+](t,z)≤0,for any z≠z^1(t):=−ε1−1lnM1−ct. By a direct computation, yields∂ϕ^−(t,z^1(t)−0)∂z=limz→z^1(t)−0{−S0M1ε1eε1(z+ct)}=−ε1S0<0.LetΓ(t,z):=−ϕ^t−(t,z)+d1ϕ^zz−(t,z)−α1ϕ^−(t,z)+f1[ϕ^−,φ^+](t,z)≥0andH(ϕ^−)(t,z,s):=e−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)∫Re−(z−y)24d1(t−s)ϕ^−(s,y)dy.Calculating the partial derivative of H(ϕ^−)(t,z,s), one has∂∂sH(ϕ^−)(t,z,s)=α1e−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)∫Re−(z−y)24d1(t−s)ϕ^−(s,y)dy+e−α1(t−s)2(t−s)4πd1(t−s)∫Re−(z−y)24d1(t−s)ϕ^−(s,y)dy−e−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)∫R(z−y)24d1(t−s)2e−(z−y)24d1(t−s)ϕ^−(s,y)dy+d1e−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)∫Re−(z−y)24d1(t−s)∂2ϕ^−(s,y)∂y2dy−e−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)∫Re−(z−y)24d1(t−s)α1ϕ^−(s,y)dy+e−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)∫Re−(z−y)24d1(t−s)[f1[ϕ^−,φ^+](s,y)−Γ(s,y)]dy.Noting ϕ^−(t,z)=0 for z>z^1(t), and using the integration by parts formula, one also hasd1e−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)∫Re−(z−y)24d1(t−s)∂2ϕ^−(s,y)∂y2dy=d1e−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)∫−∞z^1(s)e−(z−y)24d1(t−s)∂2ϕ^−(s,y)∂y2dy=d1e−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)e−(z−z^1(s))24d1(t−s)∂ϕ^−(s,z^1(s)−0)∂z−e−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)∫−∞z^1(s)e−(z−y)24d1(t−s)2(t−s)ϕ^−(s,y)dy+e−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)∫−∞z^1(s)(z−y)24d1(t−s)2e−(z−y)24d1(t−s)ϕ^−(s,y)dy.Recalling ∂ϕ^−(t,z^1(t)−0)∂z=−ε1S0, we obtain∂∂sH(ϕ^−)(t,z,s)=−ε1S0d1e−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)e−(z−z^1(s))24d1(t−s)+d1e−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)∫Re−(z−y)24d1(t−s)[f1[ϕ^−,φ^+](s,y)−Γ(s,y)]dy.Sinced1e−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)e−(z−z^1(s))24d1(t−s)∂ϕ^−(s,z^1(s)−0)∂zis integrable on s∈[0,t), noting the continuity of ∂∂sH(ϕ^−)(t,z,s) in s∈[0,t), from (Chapter I, [40]) we knowlims→t−0T(t−s)ϕ^−(t,z)=lims→t−0e−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)∫Re−(z−y)24d1(t−s)ϕ^−(s,y)dy=ϕ^−(t,z).Therefore,ϕ^−(t,z)=limη→0+H(ϕ^−)(t,z,t−η)=H(ϕ^−)(t,z,0)+limη→0+∫0t−η∂∂sH(ϕ^−)(t,z,s)ds=e−α1t4πd1t∫Re−(z−y)24d1tϕ^−(0,y)dy−ε1S0∫0td1e−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)e−(z−z^1(s))24d1(t−s)ds+∫0te−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)∫Re−(z−y)24d1(t−s)[f1[ϕ^−,φ^+](s,y)−Γ(s,y)]dyds.Due to Γ(s,y)≥0, it follows from above equality thatϕ^−(t,z)≤e−α1t4πd1t∫Re−(z−y)24d1tϕ^−(0,y)dy+∫0te−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)∫Re−(z−y)24d1(t−s)f1[ϕ^−,φ^+](s,y)dyds.By the definition of ϕ^−(t,z) and φ^+(t,z) and applying an integral transformation, we obtainϕ−(t,z+ct)≤e−α1t4πd1t∫Re−(z−y)24d1tϕ−(0,y)dy+∫0te−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)∫Re−(z−y)24d1(t−s)f1[ϕ−,φ+](s,y+cs)dyds=e−α1t4πd1t∫Re−(z−y)24d1tϕ−(0,y)dy+∫0te−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)∫Re−(z−y+cs)24d1(t−s)f1[ϕ−,φ+](s,y)dyds.In the above inequality, let z^=z+ct, we obtainϕ−(t,z^)≤e−α1t4πd1t∫Re−(z^−y−ct)24d1tϕ−(0,y)dy+∫0te−α1(t−s)4πd1(t−s)∫Re−(z^−y−c(t−s))24d1(t−s)f1[ϕ−,φ+](s,y)dyds=T1(t)ϕ−(0)+∫0tT1(t−s)f1[ϕ−,φ+](s)ds,which implies that inequality (33) holds. By using the same scheme as above, we can also prove that inequality (34) holds. The proof is completed. □

With the aids of the discussions of above lemma, we obtain the following invariance of integral system (29).Lemma 8
Let(ϕ(t,z;ϕ0,φ0),φ(t,z;ϕ0,φ0))be the solution of integral system(29)with initial value(ϕ0,φ0)∈D˜. Thenϕ−(t,z)≤ϕ(t,z;ϕ0,φ0)≤ϕ+(t,z),φ−(t,z)≤φ(t,z;ϕ0,φ0)≤min{φ+(t,z),Λε},for(t,z)∈[0,T]×R. Proof
Since (ϕ˜,φ˜)∈D and (ϕ0,φ0)∈D˜, then ϕ−≤ϕ˜≤ϕ+,φ−≤φ˜≤min{φ+,Λε} andϕ−(0,z)≤ϕ0(z)≤ϕ+(0,z),φ−(0,z)≤φ0(z)≤min{φ+(0,z),Λε}.Recalling ϕ+(t,z)=S0, we have ϕt+=d1ϕzz+−cϕz+−α1ϕ++α1ϕ+=A1ϕ++α1ϕ+. Since the analytic semigroup T1(t) generated by operator A1, we have(35)ϕ+(t)=T1(t)ϕ+(0)+α1∫0tT1(t−s)ϕ+(s)ds.Combining the positivity of semigroup T1(·) and (35), one has∫0tT1(t−s)f1[ϕ˜,φ˜](s)ds≤α1∫0tT1(t−s)ϕ+(s)ds=ϕ+(t)−T1(t)ϕ+(0)≤ϕ+(t)−T1(t)ϕ0,t∈(0,T].Consequently T1(t)ϕ0+∫0tT1(t−s)f1[ϕ˜,φ˜](s)ds≤ϕ+(t), thus ϕ(t,z;ϕ0,φ0)≤ϕ+(t,z) for any (t,z)∈[0,T]×R.
Now we prove ϕ(t,z;ϕ0,φ0)≥ϕ−(t,z). Let Φ(t,z)=ϕ(t,z;ϕ0,φ0)−ϕ−(t,z), from inequality (33), we obtainΦ(t)=T1(t)[ϕ0−ϕ−(0)]+∫0tT1(t−s)(α1[ϕ˜(s)−ϕ−(s)]−β(s)[f(ϕ˜,φ˜)−f(ϕ−,φ+)](s))ds≥T1(t)[ϕ0−ϕ−(0)]+∫0tT1(t−s)(α1[ϕ˜−ϕ−](s)−mβ(s)[ϕ˜−ϕ−](s))ds.Since α1>mβ^ and ϕ˜−ϕ−≥0, we have Φ(t)≥0, therefore, ϕ(t,z;ϕ0,φ0)≥ϕ−(t,z),(t,z)∈[0,T]×R. Next, we consider φ(t,z;ϕ0,φ0). Recalling α2>maxt∈[0,T]γ(t)+2εΛε, we know that∫0tT2(t−s)f2[ϕ˜,φ˜](s)ds=∫0tT2(t−s)[α2φ˜+βf(ϕ˜,φ˜)−γφ˜−εφ˜2](s)ds≤∫0tT2(t−s)[α2φ++(βfI(S0,0)−γ)φ+−εφ+2](s)ds,for t∈(0,T]. Recalling (32), we have∫0tT2(t−s)f2[ϕ˜,φ˜](s)ds≤φ+(t)−T2(t)φ+(0)≤φ+(t)−T2(t)φ0,t∈(0,T].According to φ(0,z)=φ0(z)≤φ+(t,z) for all z∈R, yieldsφ(t,z;ϕ0,φ0)≤φ+(t,z),forallt∈[0,T],z∈R.Since φΛε+(t,z)≡Λε satisfies φΛεt+=A1φΛε++α2φΛε+, we haveφΛε+(t,z)=T2(t)φΛε+(0,z)+α2∫0tT2(t−s)φΛε+(s,z)ds.Combining β(t)f(S0,Λε)−γ(t)Λε−εΛε2<0, and a similar arguments as above, one hasφ(t,z;ϕ0,φ0)≤φΛε+(t,z)≡Λεforallt∈[0,T],z∈R.Additionally, from the positiveness of T2(·), α2>maxt∈[0,T]γ(t)+2εΛε and (34), we obtain∫0tT2(t−s)f2[ϕ˜,φ˜](s)ds≥∫0tT2(t−s)f2[ϕ−,φ−](s)ds≥φ−(t)−T2(t)φ−(0)≥φ−(t)−T2(t)φ0,therefore, φ(t)=T2(t)φ0+∫0tT2(t−s)f2[ϕ˜,φ˜](s)ds≥φ−(t) for t∈(0,T]. Since φ(0,z)=φ0(z)≥φ−(0,z) for any z∈R, we get φ(t,z;ϕ0,φ0)≥φ−(t,z),(t,z)∈[0,T]×R. This completes the proof. □

Define time-T map of system (29) :(ϕ0(z),φ0(z))↦(ϕ(T,z;ϕ0,φ0),φ(T,z;ϕ0,φ0)) as follows.Γ(ϕ˜,φ˜)(ϕ0(·),φ0(·))=(ϕ(T,·;ϕ0,φ0),φ(T,·;ϕ0,φ0)). Theorem 1
For any given(ϕ˜,φ˜)∈D,mapΓ(ϕ˜,φ˜)has a unique fixed point(ϕ*,φ*)∈D. Proof
Lemma 8 implies Γ(ϕ˜,φ˜)(D˜)⊂D˜. Let (ϕ˜,φ˜)∈D, then fi[ϕ˜,φ˜](t,·)∈C([0,T],C(R)), and fi[ϕ˜,φ˜] are uniformly bounded with respect to (ϕ˜,φ˜)∈D,i=1,2. Using Lemma 1 we know that (ϕ,φ) defined by system (29) belongs to C([0,T]×R,R)∩Cθ,2θ([ϵ,T]×R,R) for arbitrary ϵ∈(0,T) and 0<θ<1, moreover, there exist C1,C2>0 dependent on ϵ,θ satisfying(36)∥ϕ(T,·)∥C2θ(R)≤C1(ϵ−θ∥ϕ0∥∞+∥f1[ϕ˜,φ˜]∥∞)and(37)∥φ(T,·)∥C2θ(R)≤C2(ϵ−θ∥φ0∥∞+∥f2[ϕ˜,φ˜]∥∞).Combining the estimates (36) and (37), we know that {(ϕ(T,·;ϕ0,φ0),φ(T,·;ϕ0,φ0)):(ϕ0,φ0)∈D˜} is compact on C(Ω,R2). Next, we need to prove the compactness and continuity of Γ(ϕ˜,φ˜):D˜→D˜. For any given sequences {(ϕ0n,φ0n)}⊂D˜, let Γ(ϕ0n,φ0n)=(ϕn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n), φn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n)),n=1,2,…. Due to ϕn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n) and φn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n) satisfy the (36) and (37), therefore, we can choose a subsequence of {(ϕn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n), φn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n))}, for presentation convenience, still labeled by {(ϕn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n), φn(T,·; ϕ0n,φ0n))}, satisfying (ϕn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n), φn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n))→(ϕ*(T,·;ϕ0*,φ0*),φ*(T,·;ϕ0*,φ0*)) as n→∞ in Cloc([0,T]×R,R2), in other words, for any Z∈R+, (38)limn→∞∥(ϕn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n),φn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n))−(ϕ*(T,·;ϕ0*,φ0*),φ*(T,·;ϕ0*,φ0*))∥C([0,T]×[−Z,Z],R2)=0.
Next, we will prove thatlimn→∞∥(ϕn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n),φn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n)−(ϕ*(T,·;ϕ0*,φ0*),φ*(T,·;ϕ0*,φ0*)∥μ=0.The boundedness of D˜ means∥(ϕn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n),φn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n))−(ϕ*(T,·;ϕ0*,φ0*),φ*(T,·;ϕ0*,φ0*))∥μalso uniformly bounded for n∈N+. For any given δ>0, we can choose constant Z*>0 satisfying(39)e−μ|z||(ϕn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n),φn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n))−(ϕ*(T,·;ϕ0*,φ0*),φ*(T,·;ϕ0*,φ0*))|<δfor |z|>Z* and n∈N+. Additionally, it follows from (38) that there exists N*∈N+ such that(40)e−μ|z||(ϕn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n),φn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n))−(ϕ*(T,·;ϕ0*,φ0*),φ*(T,·;ϕ0*,φ0*))|<δfor z∈[−Z*,Z*] and n>N*. Thus, it follows from the inequalities (39) and (40) that (ϕn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n),φn(T,·;ϕ0n,φ0n))→(ϕ*(T,·;ϕ0*,φ0*),φ*(T,·;ϕ0*,φ0*)) as n→∞ with respect to the norm ∥·∥μ. Therefore, the Shauder’s fixed point theorem ensures that Γ(ϕ˜,φ˜) admits a fixed point (ϕ0*,φ0*)∈D˜ satisfying ϕ(T,z;ϕ0*,φ0*)=ϕ0*(z) and φ(T,z;ϕ0*,φ0*)=φ0*(z) for any z∈R. Finally, we show that the uniqueness of (ϕ0*,φ0*). Suppose that there exists (ϕ0**,φ0**) satisfying ϕ(T,z;ϕ0**,φ0**)=ϕ0**(z), φ(T,z;ϕ0**,φ0**)=φ0**(z) for any z∈R. We have|ϕ(T,z;ϕ0*,φ0*)−ϕ(T,z;ϕ0**,φ0**)|≤e−α1T∫Re−(z−x−cT)24d1T4πd1T|ϕ0*(x)−ϕ0**(x)|dx≤∥ϕ0*(·)−ϕ0**(·)∥L∞e−α1T∫Re−(z−x−cT)24d1T4πd1Tdx=e−α1T∥ϕ0*(·)−ϕ0**(·)∥L∞.However, due to ϕ(T,·;ϕ0*,φ0*)=ϕ0*(·),ϕ(T,·;ϕ0**,φ0**)=ϕ0**(·), thus, one has∥ϕ0*(·)−ϕ0**(·)∥L∞≤e−α1T∥ϕ0*(·)−ϕ0**(·)∥L∞,which contradicts with e−α1T<1. Consequently, ϕ0*(·)=ϕ0**(·). φ0*(·)=φ0**(·) can be obtained similarly. □ Remark 1
It is clear that the fixed point (ϕ*,φ*) of map Γ(ϕ˜,φ˜) is the solution of system (29) defined on [0,T].
From Theorem 1 we define an operator F:D→Bμ as followsF(ϕ˜,φ˜)=(ϕ*,φ*),(ϕ˜,φ˜)∈D.

To obtain the fixed point of operator F, we need to prove the following conclusions.Lemma 9
The operatorF:D→Dis continuous inBμ([0,T]×R,R2). Proof
For any given (ϕi˜,φi˜)∈D, let (ϕi*(t,z;ϕi˜,φi˜),φi*(t,z;ϕi˜,φi˜))=F(ϕi˜,φi˜),i=1,2. Using (30) and the first equation of system (29), we deduce thatϕi*(T,z;ϕi˜,φi˜)=e−αiT∫R14πd1Te−(z−y−cT)24d1Tϕi*(0,y)dy+∫0Te−αi(T−s)∫R14πd1(T−s)e−(z−y−c(T−s))24d1(T−s)f1[ϕi˜,φi˜](s,y)dyds=e−αiT∫R14πd1Te−(z−y−cT)24d1Tϕi*(0,y)dy+∫0Te−αis∫R14πd1se−(z−y−cs)24d1sf1[ϕi˜,φi˜](T−s,y)dyds.Let b:=max{β^f(S0)g′(0),β^mg(Λ)}. Taking μ small enough such that ed1Tμ2+cTμ−α1T≤14, yields|ϕ1*(T,z;ϕ1˜,φ1˜)−ϕ2*(T,z;ϕ2˜,φ2˜)|e−μ|z|≤e−α1T∫R14πd1Te−(z−y−cT)24d1T|ϕ1*(0,y)−ϕ2*(0,y)|dye−μ|z|+∫0Te−α1s∫R14πd1se−(z−y−cs)24d1s(α1+b)(|ϕ1˜−ϕ2˜|+|φ1˜−φ2˜|)(T−s,y)dydse−μ|z|≤e−α1T∫R14πd1Te−(z−y−cT)24d1T|ϕ1*(0,y)−ϕ2*(0,y)|e−μ|y|eμ|y−z|dy+∫0Te−α1s∫R14πd1se−(z−y−cs)24d1s(α1+b)(|ϕ1˜−ϕ2˜|+|φ1˜−φ2˜|)(T−s,y)e−μ|y|×eμ|y−z|dyds≤e−α1T+μcT|ϕ1*(0)−ϕ2*(0)|μ∫R14πd1Te−(z−y−cT)24d1Teμ|z−y−cT|dy+(α1+b)(|ϕ1˜−ϕ2˜|μ+|φ1˜−φ2˜|μ)∫0Te(μc−α1)s∫R14πd1se−(z−y−cs)24d1seμ|z−y−cs|dyds≤2e(d1μ2+cμ−α1)T|ϕ1*(0)−ϕ2*(0)|μ+(α1+b)(|ϕ1˜−ϕ2˜|μ+|φ1˜−φ2˜|μ)∫0T2e(d1μ2+cμ−α1)sds≤12|ϕ1*(0)−ϕ2*(0)|μ+2(α1+b)(e(d1μ2+cμ−α1)T−1)d1μ2+cμ−α1(|ϕ1˜−ϕ2˜|μ+|φ1˜−φ2˜|μ).Let L:=4(α1+b)(e(d1μ2+cμ−α1)T−1)d1μ2+cμ−α1. Noting ϕi*(T,z;ϕi˜,φi˜)=ϕi*(0,z),i=1,2, we obtain that|ϕ1*(0)−ϕ2*(0)|μ≤L(|ϕ1˜−ϕ2˜|μ+|φ1˜−φ2˜|μ).Since ϕi*(t,z;ϕi˜,φi˜) satisfiesϕi*(t,z;ϕi˜,φi˜)=e−αit∫R14πd1te−(z−y−ct)24d1tϕi*(0,y)dy+∫0te−αis∫R14πd1se−(z−y−cs)24d1sf1[ϕi˜,φi˜](t−s,y)dyds.Therefore, the continuity of ϕ*(t,z;ϕ˜,φ˜) and φ*(t,z;ϕ˜,φ˜) in Bμ([0,T]×R,R2) can be obtained similarly. □ Lemma 10
The operatorF:D→Dis compact inBμ([0,T]×R,R2). Proof
For any given (ϕ˜,φ˜)∈D, let F(ϕ˜,φ˜)=(ϕ*,φ*), where (ϕ*,φ*) is the solution of system (29). From the estimates (36) and (37), and the uniform boundedness of f1[ϕ˜,φ˜] and f2[ϕ˜,φ˜] for any (ϕ˜,φ˜)∈D, we know that ∥ϕ*(0)∥C2θ(R)=∥ϕ*(T)∥C2θ(R)≤C and ∥φ*(0)∥C2θ(R)=∥φ*(T)∥C2θ(R)≤C for some constant C>0. Thanks to Lemma 1, we know that (ϕ*,φ*)∈Cθ,2θ([0,T]×R,R2) and there exist some C1,C2 and K˜>0 satisfying(41)∥ϕ*∥Cθ,2θ([0,T]×R)≤C1(∥ϕ*(0)∥C2θ(R)+∥f1[ϕ˜,φ˜]∥∞)≤K˜ and(42)∥φ*∥Cθ,2θ([0,T]×R)≤C2(∥φ*(0)∥C2θ(R)+∥f2[ϕ˜,φ˜]∥∞)≤K˜.For any given sequences {(ϕ˜n,φ˜n)}⊂D, let F(ϕ˜n,φ˜n)=(ϕn*,φn*),n=1,2,…. Due to ϕn* and φn* satisfying the (41) and (42) respectively, we can choose a subsequence of {(ϕn*,φn*)}, without loss of generality, still labeled by {(ϕn*,φn*)}, satisfying(ϕn*,φn*)→(ϕ**,φ**)inCloc([0,T]×R,R2),By a similar method as in Theorem 1, we can obtain ∥(ϕn*(t,z),φn*(t,z))−(ϕ**(t,z),φ**(t,z))∥μ→0 as n→∞, therefore, the operator F is compact in Bμ([0,T]×R,R2). □

Applying Lemma 9, Lemma 10 and the Schauder’s fixed point theorem, we further obtain the following theorem.Theorem 2
The operatorF:D→Dhas a fixed point(ϕ˜*,φ˜*)∈D. Remark 2
It is clear that the fixed point (ϕ˜*,φ˜*)∈D of operator F is the solution of system (14) defined on [0,T].

sec.title: Existence of periodic traveling waves
sec.p:
Now, on the basis of the above discussion we show that the existence of periodic solution for auxiliary system (14).Theorem 3
SupposeR0>1andc>c*. Then auxiliary system(14)admits a nontrival time periodic solution(ϕ*,φ*)satisfying asymptotic boundary conditions(12). Moreover,0<1T∫0Tφ*(t,z)dt≤S0−S∞,z∈Rand(43)1T∫R∫0Tγ(t)φ*(t,z)+εφ*2(t,z)dtdz=1T∫R∫0Tβ(t)f(ϕ*(t,z),φ*(t,z))dtdz=c[S0−S∞]. Proof
By the above discussion, for every c>c*, operator F admits a unique fixed point (ϕ*,φ*)∈D satisfying (ϕ*(T,·),φ*(T,·))=(ϕ*(0,·),φ*(0,·)), moreover(44){ϕ*(t)=T1(t)ϕ*(0)+∫0tT1(t−s)f1[ϕ*,φ*](s)ds,φ*(t)=T2(t)φ*(0)+∫0tT2(t−s)f2[ϕ*,φ*](s)ds,for 0≤t≤T. Denote (ϕ*^(t,z),φ^*(t,z))=(ϕ*(t−nT,z),φ*(t−nT,z)), where integers n can be chosen to satisfy nT≤t<(n+1)T. We can verify that ϕ*^(t,z) and φ^*(t,z) are T-periodic function for (t,z)∈R×R. From (ϕ*,φ*)∈Cθ,2θ([0,T]×R,R2), we know that (ϕ^*,φ^*)∈Cθ,2θ(R×R,R2). It is clear that (ϕ^*,φ^*) satisfies following system(45){ϕ^*(t)=T1(t)ϕ^*(0)+∫0tT1(t−s)f1[ϕ^*,φ^*](s)ds,φ^*(t)=T2(t)φ^*(0)+∫0tT2(t−s)f2[ϕ^*,φ^*](s)ds,for t∈R. Without loss of generality, (ϕ^*,φ^*) still labeled by (ϕ*,φ*). Thanks to ([41], Theorem 5.1.2, 5.1.3, 5.1.4), it follows that (ϕ*,φ*)∈C1,2+2θ(R×R,R2) satisfies(46){ϕt*=d1ϕzz*−cϕz*−β(t)f(ϕ*,φ*),φt*=d2φzz*−cφz*+β(t)f(ϕ*,φ*)−γ(t)φ*−εφ*2for t∈R,z∈R. Moreover,(47)∥ϕ*∥C1,2+2θ(R×R,R)+∥φ*∥C1,2+2θ(R×R,R)<∞forsomeθ∈(0,1).It is clear that limz→−∞ϕ*(t,z)=S0 and limz→−∞φ*(t,z)=0 uniformly for t∈R. Now, we intend to show that the second equality of (43). To obtain this, we need to investigate the asymptotic behavior of (ϕz*,φz*) and (ϕzz*,φzz*) as z→−∞. Using the estimate (47) and Landau type inequalities (See [45]), for any given M<∞, we have|ϕz*|L∞([0,T]×(−∞,M])≤2|ϕ*−S0|L∞([0,T]×(−∞,M])12|ϕzz*|L∞([0,T]×(−∞,M])12,and|φz*|L∞([0,T]×(−∞,M])≤2|φ*−S0|L∞([0,T]×(−∞,M])12|φzz*|L∞([0,T]×(−∞,M])12.Consequently,(48)limz→−∞(ϕz*(t,z),φz*(t,z))=(0,0)uniformlyfort∈R.Taking the partial derivatives with respect to z on both sides of the first equation of (46), yields(49)(ϕz*)t=d1(ϕz*)zz−c(ϕz*)z−β(t)(fS(ϕ*,φ*)ϕz*+fI(ϕ*,φ*)φz*).Applying ([41], Theorem 5.1.3, 5.1.4), we know that ϕz*∈C1,2+2θ(R×R,R) and ∥ϕz*∥C1,2+2θ(R×R,R)<∞. Repeating the above procedure and Landau type inequality, one can see that(50)limz→−∞(ϕzz*(t,z),φzz*(t,z))=(0,0)uniformlyfort∈R.Consider the system (46), combining the (48) and (50), we havelimz→−∞(ϕt*(t,z),φt*(t,z))=(0,0)uniformlyfort∈R.Setting Φ(z):=1T∫0Tϕ*(t,z)dt. It follows from (48) that Φz(z)→0 as z→−∞. From the first equation of (46), we have(51)cΦz=d1Φzz−1T∫0Tβ(t)f(ϕ*,φ*)dt.By integrating (51) from −∞ to z, we obtain(52)d1Φz(z)=c[Φ(z)−S0]+1T∫−∞z∫0Tβ(t)f(ϕ*(t,y),φ*(t,y))dtdy.It follows from uniform boundedness of ϕ*(t,z) and ϕz*(t,z) that Φ(z)=1T∫0Tϕ*(t,z)dt and Φz(z)=1T∫0Tϕz*(t,z)dt are bounded. Therefore, from (52) we know1T∫0Tβ(t)f(ϕ*(t,z),φ*(t,z))dt<∞.Combining (51), it follows that(e−cz/d1Φz)z=e−cz/d1(Φzz−cΦz/d1)=e−cz/d1d1T∫0Tβ(t)f(ϕ*(t,z),φ*(t,z))dt.Integrating above equality from z to ∞, we finde−cz/d1Φz(z)=−1d1T∫z∞e−cy/d1∫0Tβ(t)f(ϕ*(t,y),φ*(t,y))dtdy.Hence, Φz(z)<0 for all z∈R, which indicates that Φ(+∞) exists and let Φ(+∞):=S∞. Clearly, S∞=Φ(+∞)<Φ(−∞)=S0. On the other hand, applying the Barbaˇlat’s lemma (See [46]), it follows that Φz(z)→0 as z→+∞. Taking z→∞ in (52), we find that(53)1T∫−∞∞∫0Tβ(t)f(ϕ*,φ*)dtdz=c[S0−Φ(∞)]=c[S0−S∞].
Next, we consider the limitation of φ*(t,z) as z→∞. Let γ_:=mint∈[0,T]γ(t) and Ψ(z):=1T∫0Tφ*(t,z)dt. Combining the second equation of (46), one has(54)−d2Ψzz+cΨz+γ_Ψ=1T∫0T[β(t)f(ϕ*,φ*)−(γ(t)−γ_)φ*−εφ*2]dt.The two roots of the characteristic equation −d2λ2+cλ+γ_=0 are denoted byλ−=c−c2+4d2γ_2d2<0,λ+=c+c2+4d2γ_2d2>0.Let ρ˜:=d2(λ+−λ−)=c2+4d2γ_. Then, it follows from (54) thatΨ(z)≤1ρ˜T∫0∞eλ−y∫0Tβ(t)f(ϕ*(t,z−y),φ*(t,z−y))dtdy+1ρ˜T∫−∞0eλ+y∫0Tβ(t)f(ϕ*(t,z−y),φ*(t,z−y))dtdy.Integrating from η to ξ on both sides of above equation, we have∫ηξΨ(z)dz≤1ρ˜T∫0∞eλ−y∫ηξ∫0Tβ(t)f(ϕ*(t,z−y),φ*(t,z−y))dtdzdy+1ρ˜T∫−∞0eλ+y∫ηξ∫0Tβ(t)f(ϕ*(t,z−y),φ*(t,z−y))dtdzdy.From (53) we know that ∫0Tβ(t)f(ϕ*,φ*)dt is integrable on R. The Fubini′s theorem (See [47]) ensures that Ψ(z) is integrable on R, and∫−∞∞Ψ(z)dz≤1γ_T∫−∞∞∫0Tβ(t)f(ϕ*(t,z),φ*(t,z))dtdz.By a similar argument as the boundedness of Φz(z), we can obtain that Ψz(z) is bounded on R. Therefore, the Barba˘rlat’s lemma guarantees Ψ(z)→0 as z→∞. We consider the second equation of system (46), taking τ=−T,θ=T and D=(ξ−14,ξ+14),U=(ξ−12,ξ+12),Ω=(ξ−1,ξ+1) with ξ∈R. Then, the Lemma 2 means that there is a constant C0>0 independent of D such thatsup(0,T)×Dφ*(t,z)≤C0inf(2T,3T)×Dφ*(t,z)=C0min[2T,3T]×D¯φ*(t,z)≤C0minD¯φ*(0,z).Now, we show that limz→∞φ*(0,z)=0. Suppose that this conclusion is false, then there exists a constant δ>0 and sequence {zn} satisfying zn→∞ as n→∞ such that limn→∞φ*(0,zn)≥δ. The continuity of φ*(t,z) with respect to t implies that there exists constant σ>0 such that limn→∞φ*(t,zn)≥δ for all 0≤t≤σ. We deduce thatlimn→∞Ψ(zn)=limn→∞1T∫0Tφ*(t,zn)dt≥limn→∞1T∫0σφ*(t,zn)dt≥1T∫0σφ*(t,zn)dt≥δσT,which is a contradiction with limz→∞Ψ(z)=0. Thus limz→∞φ*(0,z)=0, combining the periodicity of φ*, we can obtain φ*(t,z)→0 uniformly for t∈R as z→∞.
Next, let(55)limz→∞supmaxt∈[0,T]ϕ*(t,z)=:S+∞,limz→∞infmint∈[0,T]ϕ*(t,z):=S−∞.Thanks to the T-periodicity of ϕ*, we need to show S+∞=S∞=S−∞. From (55), we know that there exist sequences {tn} and {zn} with {tn}⊂[0,T] and zn→∞ as n→∞, satisfying limn→∞ϕ*(tn,zn)=S+∞. Letting ϕn(t,z):=ϕ*(t+tn,z+zn) and φn(t,z):=φ*(t+tn,z+zn),n∈N+,t∈R,z∈R. The estimation (47) implies that we can choose a subsequence of {(ϕn(t,z),φn(t,z))}, without loss of generality, still denoted by {(ϕn(t,z),φn(t,z))}, satisfying (ϕn(t,z),φn(t,z))→(ϕ*(t,z),0)∈Clocθ,2θ(R×R) as n→∞. Consequently, ϕ*(0,0)=S+∞, ϕ*(t,z) is a T-periodic function, and ϕ*(t,z)≤S+∞ for all (t,z)∈R×R.
Due to {tn}⊂[0,T], there exists a t*∈[0,T] such that tn→t* as n→∞. Let ϕ*+(t,z):=ϕ*(t−t*,z), then ϕ*+(t,z) satisfiesϕ*+(t)=T1(t)ϕ*+(0)+∫0tT1(t−s)f1[ϕ*+,0](s)ds=T1(t)ϕ*+(0)+∫0tT1(t−s)α1ϕ*+(s)ds.Further, we know ϕ*t+=d1ϕ*zz+−cϕ*z+. Due to ϕ*+(t*,0)=S+∞ and ϕ*+(t,z)≤S+∞, then the maximum principle guarantees ϕ*+(t,z)≡S+∞, that is 1T∫0Tϕ*+(t,z)dt≡S+∞ for all t∈R. Next, let Φ*+(z):=1T∫0Tϕ*+(t,z)dt, then Φ*+(z)≡S+∞. Furthermore, one can seeΦ*+(z)=1T∫0Tϕ*+(t,z)dt=limn→∞1T∫0Tϕ*(t−t*+tn,z+zn)dt=S∞,which indicates S+∞=S∞. Thus limz→∞supmaxt∈[0,T]ϕ*(t,z)=S∞. Similarly, we can show that limz→∞infmint∈[0,T]ϕ*(t,z)=S∞. Therefore, ϕ*+(t,z)→S∞ uniformly for t∈R as z→∞.
Finally, by using Landau type inequalities to ϕz*(t,z) and ϕzz*(t,z), we can deduce(56)limz→±∞φz*(t,z)=limz→±∞φzz*(t,z)=0,uniformlyfort∈R.From the (54), we have(57)−d2Ψzz+cΨz=1T∫0T[β(t)f(ϕ*,φ*)−γ(t)φ*−εφ*2]dt.Making an integration to Eq. (57) on R, combining the (53) and (56), we obtain(58)1T∫R∫0T[γ(t)φ*+εφ*2]dtdz=1T∫R∫0Tβ(t)f(ϕ*,φ*)dtdz=c[S0−S∞].Define(59)Ψ*(z):=1cT∫−∞z∫0T[γ(t)φ*(t,y)+εφ*2(t,y)]dtdy+1cT∫z∞ec(z−y)d2∫0T[γ(t)φ*(t,y)+εφ*2(t,y)]dtdy.It is clear that function Ψ*(z) satisfies(60)cΨz*(z)=d2Ψzz*(z)+1T∫0T[γ(t)φ*(t,z)+εφ*2(t,z)]dt,∀z∈R.Combining (56), (58) and L’Ho^pital’s rule, we have(61)limz→−∞Ψ*(z)=0,limz→∞Ψ*(z)=1cT∫R∫0T[γ(t)φ*(t,y)+εφ*2(t,y)]dtdy=S0−S∞and limz→±∞Ψz*(z)=0. Note that Ψ(z)=1T∫0Tφ*(t,z)dt. Let Ψ^(z):=Ψ(z)+Ψ*(z),z∈R. Combining (57) and (60), we find(62)cΨ^z(z)=d2Ψ^zz(z)+1T∫0Tβ(t)f(ϕ*,φ*)dt,z∈R.Multiplying by e−cz/d2 to two sides of the (62) and integrating from z to ∞, yieldsΨ^z(z)=1d2T∫z∞e−c(y−z)d2∫0Tβ(t)f(ϕ*,φ*)dt≥0,which implies that Ψ^(z) is nondecreasing in R. On the other hand, it follows from (62) and (63) that limz→∞Ψ^(z)=S0−S∞. Therefore, Ψ(z)≤Ψ^(z)≤S0−S∞, that is 0<1T∫0Tφ*(t,z)dt≤S0−S∞ for all z∈R. □

Now, to return system (11), we obtain the following conclusion.Theorem 4
SupposeR0>1andc>c*. Then system(11)admits a time periodic solution(ϕ*,φ*)satisfying asymptotic boundary conditions(12). Moreover,0<1T∫0Tφ*(t,z)dt≤S0−S∞,z∈Rand(63)1T∫R∫0Tγ(t)φ*(t,z)dtdz=1T∫R∫0Tβ(t)f(ϕ*(t,z),φ*(t,z))dtdz=c[S0−S∞]. Proof
Let {εn}⊂(0,1) is a decreasing sequence and εn→0 as n→∞. Theorem 3 guarantees that system (14) admits a solution sequence {(ϕn*(t,z),φn*(t,z))} with ε=εn,(n=1,2,…), satisfying(64){(ϕn*)t=d1(ϕn*)zz−c(ϕn*)z−β(t)f(ϕn*,φn*),(φn*)t=d2(φn*)zz−c(φn*)z+β(t)f(ϕn*,φn*)−γ(t)φn*−εnφn*2and0<1T∫0Tφn*(t,z)dt≤S0−S∞,z∈R.Moreover,(65)1T∫R∫0Tγ(t)φn*(t,z)+εnφn*2(t,z)dtdz=1T∫R∫0Tβ(t)f(ϕn*(t,z),φn*(t,z))dtdz=c[S0−S∞].Furthermore, we know thatφ−(t,z)≤φn*(t,z)≤S0andφ−(t,z)≤φn*(t,z)≤min{φ+(t,z),Λεn},n∈N+.It follows from Λε=maxt∈[0,T]{β(t)fI(S0,0)−γ(t)ε} that Λεn→∞ as n→∞.
For z∈[−k,k],k=1,2,…, there exists nk∈N+ such that φ+(t,z)=K(t)eλ1z<Λεn for all n>nk,z∈[−k,k] and t∈[0,T]. Therefore, solution sequences {(ϕn*(t,z),φn*(t,z))} are equi-continuous and uniformly bounded on z∈[−k,k]. The Arzela`-Ascoli theorem means that there exists a uniformly convergent subsequences {(ϕk,m*(t,z),φk,m*(t,z))} of {(ϕn*(t,z),φn*(t,z))} as m→∞.
It’s not hard to see that there is a subsequence {(ϕm,m*(t,z), φm,m*(t,z))}, which uniformly converges on every interval [−k,k](k=1,2,3,…). Let limm→∞(ϕm,m*(t,z),φm,m*(t,z))=(ϕ*(t,z),φ*(t,z)). For every m∈N+, we know(66){(ϕm,m*)t=d1(ϕm,m*)zz−c(ϕm,m*)z−β(t)f(ϕm,m*,φm,m*),(φm,m*)t=d2(φm,m*)zz−c(φm,m*)z+β(t)f(ϕm,m*,φm,m*)−γ(t)φm,m*−εm,m(φm,m*)2.Let m→∞, we know that limm→∞εm,m=0. Thus, (ϕ*(t,z),φ*(t,z)) satisfies system (11). Combining Theorem 3 and (65), we know that 0≤1T∫0Tφ*(t,z)dt≤S0−S∞ and (63) holds. Finally, we need to prove 1T∫0Tφ*(t,z)dt>0. It follows from φ−(t,z)≤φ*(t,z)≤φ+(t,z) and φ−(t,z)=max{K(t)eλ1z(1−M2eε2z),0} thatφ*(t,z)≥0forall(t,z)∈R×Rand(67)φ*(t,z)>0foranyt∈[0,T],z<z2=−ε2−1lnM2.Therefore, we have{φt*(t,z)=d2φ*zz−cφ*z+β(t)f(ϕ*,φ*)−γ(t)φ*≥d2φ*zz−cφ*z−γ(t)φ*,(t,z)∈(0,T]×R,φ*(t,z)≥0,(t,z)∈(0,T]×R,φ*(0,z)≥0,z∈R.From (67), we have φ*(0,z)≢0 for z∈R. By the maximum principle (see, [48]), we know that φ*(t,z)>0 on R×R and 1T∫0Tφ*(t,z)dt>0. This completes the proof. □ Remark 3
It is clear that when incidence functions f(S,I)=SI and f(S,I)=SIS+I, then assumptions (A1) and (A2) are satisfied. Therefore, the main results on the existence of periodic travelling wave solutions for models (1) and (2) obtained in [31], [35] are the direct corollaries of Theorem 4.

sec.title: Nonexistence of periodic traveling waves
sec.p:
In what follows, we shall establish the non-existence of periodic traveling wave solutions for R0≤1 or R0>1 and 0<c<c*.Theorem 5
Assume thatR0≤1andc≥0,then there does not exist nonnegative and periodic traveling wave solution(ϕ*,φ*)satisfying asymptotic boundary conditions(12). Proof
Suppose that there exists a periodic traveling wave solution (ϕ*,φ*) for system (11) satisfying (12). Then, we have(68)φt*=d2φzz*−cφz*+β(t)fI(S0,0)φ*−γ(t)φ*+β(t)f(ϕ*,φ*)−β(t)fI(S0,0)φ*,for t>0,z∈R. Let Ψ˜(t):=∫Rφ*(t,z)dz. Integrating (68) with respect to z on R, and combining asymptotic boundary conditions (12) and (15), yieldsΨ˜t(t)=(β(t)fI(S0,0)−γ(t))Ψ˜(t)+m(t),where m(t)=β(t)∫R[f(ϕ*,φ*)−fI(S0,0)φ*]dz<0. Due to Ψ˜(t) and m(t) are T-periodic, we haveΨ˜t(t)Ψ˜(t)=(β(t)fI(S0,0)−γ(t))+m(t)Ψ˜(t),t∈R.Integrating above equality from 0 to T, combining the periodicity of Ψ˜(t), yields0=∫0T(β(t)fI(S0,0)−γ(t))dt+∫0Tm(t)Ψ˜(t)dt.Note that R0≤1, which implies ∫0T[β(t)fI(S0,0)−γ(t)]dt≤0. Combining the m(t)<0, yields0=∫R(β(t)fI(S0,0)−γ(t))dt+∫Rm(t)Ψ˜(t)<0,which is a contradiction. This is the end of the proof. □ Theorem 6
AssumeR0>1,then system(11)does not have a periodic traveling wave solution(ϕ*,φ*)satisfying asymptotic boundary conditions(12)for anyc∈(0,c*). Proof
Assume that the solution (ϕ(t,x+c˜t),φ(t,x+c˜t)) is a traveling wave solution satisfying conditions (12) for some 0<c˜<c*=2d2∫0T[β(t)fI(S0,0)−γ(t)]dtT. Since R0=∫0Tβ(t)fI(S0,0)dt∫0Tγ(t)dt>1 means ∫0T[β(t)fI(S0,0)−γ(t)]dt>0, which implies that there exists a sufficiently small δ0>0 such that ∫0T[β(t)(fI(S0,0)−δ0)−γ(t)]dt>0. Letωδ:=1T∫0T[β(t)(fI(S0,0)−δ)−γ(t)]dt,δ∈(0,δ0).We can choose a δ∈(0,δ0) satisfying c˜<2d2ωδ.
Fixed a constant c0∈(c˜,2d2ωδ) and let Nc0=4d2ωδ−c022d2. DefineGδ(t)=exp(∫0t[β(s)(fI(S0,0)−δ)−γ(s)]ds−ωδt).Obviously, Gtδ(t)=[β(t)(fI(S0,0)−δ)−γ(t)]Gδ(t)−ωδGδ(t). Define a function ψc0(t,z):=ec0z2d2sin(Nc0z)Gδ(t). We can deduce ψc0(t+T,z)=ψc0(t,z) for any z∈R. Then, by a direct calculation, yields(69)ψtc0(t,z)=d2ψzzc0(t,z)−c0ψzc0(t,z)+[β(t)(fI(S0,0)−δ)−γ(t)]ψc0(t,z).We choose n0∈N+ such that (2n0−1)πNc0>Nδ. Further, we can choose y1=−2n0πNc0,y2=−(2n0−1)πNc0. Then, we have sin(Nc0y1)=sin(Nc0y2)=0 and sin(Nc0z)>0 for all z∈(y1,y2). Since φ(0,z) is strictly positive on interval [y1,y2], thus we can find a constant ϵ>0 satisfying ϵψc0(0,z)≤φ(0,z) for all z∈[y1,y2]. Define φ^(t,x):=φ(t,x+(c−c0)t). Since (ϕ(t,z),φ(t,z)) is a solution of system (11), we have(70)φ^t(t,x)=d2φ^xx(t,x)−c0φ^x(t,x)+β(t)f(ϕ(t,x+(c−c0)t),φ^(t,x))−γ(t)φ^(t,x).Due to limz→−∞ϕ(t,z)=S0 and limz→−∞φ(t,z)=0 uniformly for t∈R, combining (A2), we can deduce that there exists a Nδ>0 satisfying f(ϕ,φ)≥(fI(S0,0)−δ)φ for all z<−Nδ uniformly for t∈R. Since c−c0<0 and y1<y2<−Nδ, we have x+(c−c0)t≤−Nδ for all t≥0,x∈[y1,y2]. Therefore, from (70) we know(71)φ^t(t,x)≥d2φ^xx(t,x)−c0φ^x(t,x)+[β(t)(fI(S0,0)−δ)−γ(t)]φ^(t,x),for x∈[y1,y2]. Let φˇ(t,x):=φ(t,x+(c−c0)t)−ϵψc0(t,z)=φ^(t,x)−ϵψc0(t,z) for all t≥0,x∈[y1,y2]. It follows from (69) and (71) that{φˇt(t,x)≥d2φˇxx(t,x)−c0φˇx(t,x)+[β(t)(fI(S0,0)−δ)−γ(t)]φˇ(t,x),t≥0,x∈[y1,y2],φˇ(0,x)≥0,x∈[y1,y2],φˇ(t,yi)≥0,i=1,2.Applying the maximum principle, we can derive that φˇ≥0 for all t>0 and x∈[y1,y2], that is φ(t,x+(c−c0)t)≥ϵψc0(t,z) for all t>0 and x∈[y1,y2], which contradict with φ(t,x+(c−c0)t)→0 when t→∞ since c−c0<0. This is the end of the proof. □ Remark 4
We easily see that the main results on the non-existence of periodic travelling wave solutions for models (1) and (2) established in [31], [35] can be directly obtained form Theorems 5 and 6.

sec.title: Numerical examples
sec.p:
In this section, we present some numerical simulations to illustrate the theoretic results. Assume that the incidence function f(S,I)=SI. We choose the following initial conditionsS(0,x)={1+0.5sinx,if−20≤x<0,5.5,if0≤x≤20,I(0,x)={0.1+0.1sinx,if−20≤x<0,0,if0≤x≤20,All values of the parameters are given: β(t)=0.15*(0.1*sin(t)+1), γ(t)=0.5*(0.1*cos(t)+1), S0=5.5, d1=0.09648, d2=0.4 and d3=0.17. By simple calculation, we obtain R0=1.65>1 and c*=0.7212. Theorem 4 means that there exists traveling wave solutions satisfying the asymptotical boundary conditions (12). That is, ϕ(t,−∞)=S∞, φ(t,−∞)=0, ϕ(t,∞)=S0 and φ(t,∞)=0. The numerical simulations are given in Fig. 1 .Remark 5
It is clear that there exists a constant S∞, which stands for the steady state of susceptible individuals after the epidemic, satisfying S∞<S0=5.5. However, we still don’t obtain the exact value of S∞ through theoretical analysis. Fig. 1
Numerical simulation show that there exists traveling wave solution connecting the initial disease-free steady state (S0,0) and the steady state (S∞,0) after the epidemic. Moreover, from the numerical stimulation we can obtain S∞≈1.601.Fig. 1

Now, we observe the effect of the critical wave speed c by using the equipotential diagram. We choose all conditions and parameters are same as previous, that is R0=1.65>1 and c*=0.7212. It follows from Theorem 3 and Theorem 6 that there exists traveling waves connecting (S0,0) and (S∞,0) for every speed c>c*, and there does not exist such traveling waves for any c<c*. The numerical simulations are given in Fig. 2 .Fig. 2
Numerical simulation show that there exists traveling wave solution connecting the initial disease-free steady state (S0,0) and the steady state (S∞,0) when c>c*=0.7212, and there does not exist such traveling wave solutions if c<c*.Fig. 2

In order to find out the difference of traveling wave solution when the infection coefficient and recovery rate are related to time t or independent of time t. We choose β=0.15,γ=0.5 and assume that the rest of the parameters are same as above. We choose the following initial conditionsS(0,x)={1,if−20≤x<0,5.5,if0≤x≤20,I(0,x)={0.1,if−30≤x<0,0,if0≤x≤30,The numerical simulations are given in Figs. 3 and 4 .Fig. 3
Numerical simulation show that the traveling wave solution about susceptible individuals is more oscillatory or has a periodicity when the infection coefficient and recovery rate are related to time t than usual.Fig. 3Fig. 4
Numerical simulation show that the traveling wave solution about infected individuals is more oscillatory or has a periodicity when the infection coefficient and recovery rate are related to time t than usual.Fig. 4

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, we proposed a nonautonomous and diffusive SIR epidemic model with general nonlinear incidence given by system (3) assuming that the transmission rates and recovery rates are positive and T-periodic functions. We further investigated the existence and nonexistence of periodic traveling waves for system (3). It is important to mention that the classical methods such as shooting method [34], two-sided Laplace transform [18] and monotone iteration methods [49] can not be used directly, since the introduction of nonautonomous and nonlinear incidence. Consequently, we further refined and developed the previous methods in [31], [35]. More precisely, we constructed an auxiliary system (14) to obtain the boundedness of the infected individual, which guarantees the suitable bounded closed convex set between the upper and lower solutions. Finally, the existence of traveling wave solutions are obtained by the fixed-point theorem and some limiting arguments. Many of the methods and arguments in this investigation can be widely applied to the existence and nonexistence of periodic traveling wave solutions for other periodic reaction-diffusion systems.

The conclusions of this article show that there exists a critical wave speed c*>0 such that the system (3) admits a T-periodic traveling wave solutions (ϕ*(t,z),φ*(t,z)) satisfying the asymptotic boundary conditions (12) when the reproductive number R0>1, and there is no such solution for either R0≤1 or R0>1 and 0<c<c*. In fact, it is not difficult to find that the literatures [35] and [31] are the direct corollaries of our conclusions. Furthermore, we provided some numerical simulations to verify our theoretic results. It is not difficult to find that the traveling wave solution ϕ*(t,z) tends to a constant S∞ less than S0 as z→∞ when R0>1 and c>c*, and the exact value of S∞ can not be obtained by theoretical analysis, which will be our further research direction.

Finally, there are some very interesting problems that deserve further study. For example, on the one hand, we can consider the traveling wave solutions of the nonlocal diffusion time-periodic model. On the other hand, we can investigate the periodic model with susceptible input and natural death, because there are disease-free periodic solution and endemic periodic solution when the basic reproduction number is more than unit, so we can study the existence of traveling wave solutions connecting these two periodic solutions.
